title: Why the Mediterranean basin has become the 'hotspot' of climate crisis
description: Home to over 500 million people, the region is one of the hardest hit on the planet and is warming faster than the global average.

title: North Atlantic ocean temperature sets record high according to US agency
description: The record is particularly startling as it comes early in the year – usually, the North Atlantic reaches its peak high temperature in early September.

title: Disqualified Ukrainian fencer reinstated in world championships after refusing to shake hands with Russian opponent
description: Olha Kharlan was also awarded a place in the 2024 Paris Olympics by the IOC on Friday.

title: In Sri Lanka, the shattered dreams of reconciliation
description: Fourteen years after a war that claimed more than 100,000 lives, the memory of the conflict between the Tamil population and the Sri Lankan army.

title: Senegalese presidential candidate Ousmane Sonko arrested
description: Members of his party said the opposition figure was arrested, but no reason was given.

title: Women's Tour de France: Norsgaard the winner ahead of week-end mountains
description: Danish rider Emma Norsgaard won stage six. Belgium's Lotte Kopecky is still in yellow ahead of the final stages over the week-end.

title: Moscow accuses Ukraine of missile attack on southern Russia
description: Russia said it had intercepted two missiles, but that falling debris caused at a least a dozen injuries.

title: In China, pets are the new darlings of the golden generation
description: After conquering Shanghai, 'pet culture' is taking hold in Beijing. Even relatively small cities are investing in the sector, one of the few to maintain strong growth.

title: Climate litigation is now a 'key mechanism' against inaction, UN says
description: According to a UN report, the US overwhelmingly represents the majority of cases of climate-related litigation, but cases are on the rise elsewhere in the world.

title: Parenting: How did we end up with 'indoor children'?
description: 'Parenting, what a job!' (4/6). Gone are the days when children played in the streets and came home from school on their own. In fact, while most parents claim to want independence for their children, they tend to overprotect them out of fear.

title: Why are the journalists of France's only Sunday paper on strike?
description: Journalists at France's 'Journal du Dimanche' have been on strike for over a month. They fear that the weekly's editorial line will change radically with the appointment of right-wing journalist Geoffroy Lejeune as editorial director.

title: In Wallis and Futuna Islands, Starlink challenges France's strategic autonomy
description: France's most remote Pacific territory is racing to connect to Elon Musk's internet service provider. The surge in popularity raises national sovereignty issues that President Macron intends to address during his visit to Oceania from July 24 to 29.

title: Galloping inflation means more and more Iranians can't make rent
description: Inflation, which according to official figures approached 50% in March, is forcing Iranians to drastically slash their spending.

title: Niger: Coup-instigating general declares himself new leader
description: General Abdourahamane Tchiani, head of the Presidential Guard since 2011, declared himself president of the National Council for the Safeguard of the Homeland, two days after detaining President Mohamed Bazoum.

title: The devastating fires in Palermo spark anger and questions about responsibility
description: The fires that encircled the Sicilian city for several days have been brought under control, after causing hundreds of millions of euros of damage and five deaths.

title: French national railway company seeks to recover after tough start to 2023
description: SNCF's profits fell sharply in the first half of the year, including due to the pension reform and labor unrest, despite the strength of the high-speed TGV line.

title: Bangui, Wagner's African capital
description: The Russian paramilitary group has made itself essential to the authorities of the Central African Republic. The attempted rebellion of the group's leader, Yevgeny Prigozhin, had no impact on this privileged status.

title: Writer Roberto Saviano suspended from Italian public television
description: The show that the famous author of 'Gomorrah' was due to host on RAI in the fall has been canceled. The decision came shortly after he criticized Infrastructure Minister Matteo Salvini.

title: Chinese authorities ready to support an ailing economy
description: At a meeting on Monday, July 24, the Political Bureau of the Communist Party promised 'adjustments' as the country teeters on the brink of deflation.

title: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi moved from prison
description: The Myanmar civilian leader has been moved to a high-level venue compound on Monday night, an official from the National League for Democracy told Agence France-Presse Friday on condition of anonymity. There have been concerns about the 78-year-old Nobel laureate's health since her detention.

title: 'Making us disappear is as absurd as dismantling the Eiffel Tower': Paris and its 'bouquinistes' clash over Olympics
description: Booksellers established along the banks of the Seine river refuse to see their bookstalls removed during next year's Games.

title: Roman Abramovich's life as a gentleman in Londongrad
description: 'Roman Abramovich, the most secretive of oligarchs' (4/6). In the 2000s, the Russian businessman settled in the British capital. By buying Chelsea FC and forging friendships among the political and financial elite, he became an almost normal member of the British elite.

title: Randy Meisner, founding member of the Eagles, dies at 77
description: The singer of 'Take it to the Limit' died Wednesday night in Los Angeles of complications from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, the Eagles said Thursday. Meisner joined the band in the early 1970s to form one of the most popular acts in history.
